newsitem.title: ITALY: SOCCER SHOWCASE-GENEROUS JUVENTUS SET TO TURN MEAN.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER SHOWCASE-GENEROUS JUVENTUS SET TO TURN MEAN.

text.p: Marco Delvecchio's last-gasp equaliser against Juventus in the Italian league at the weekend delighted Roma fans but their joy at the discomfort of the European champions may be shortlived.

The mood in the Juventus camp after the 1-1 draw at the Olympic Stadium in Rome on Saturday night suggested that Delvecchio's injury-time shot could speed a change in mentality, with league leaders Juventus sharpening up their act.
Coach Marcello Lippi, whose team were held 0-0 by third division Nocerina in an Italian Cup third round tie last Wednesday, lambasted and complimented his men in almost equal measure after the match.
His men controlled the pace of the game, scored a beautiful 59th-minute goal and then gave away their advantage when second-half substitute Delvecchio scored.
Juventus have now been held in their last three away matches, all against lesser opponents, and Lippi accused his men of complacency and taking a win for granted.
"I'm sure they won't make that mistake again," he said, delivering a few choice but unrepeatable words.
But he added that he had liked what he had seen until Delvecchio's strike undid all the good work.
"We played a good game, I saw a better team in every sense -- technical, tactical and athletic," he said.

Austria's Rapid Vienna, who play Juventus in a European Champions' League clash in Turin on Wednesday after drawing 1-1 at home thanks to another late equaliser, can expect frustration to be vented on them.
Juventus lead Group C with seven points and can afford to rest several key players, such as French international Zinedine Zidane who had a workmanlike game on Saturday.
But they have strength in depth and intend to finish top of the group. All the signs are that "La Vecchia Signora" is tightening up her boot laces and squaring her jaw.
Rapid may find the tackles a little harder, the time-wasting at the end a little more evident than hitherto.
Italian international midfielder Angelo Di Livio, the outstanding player against Roma on Saturday, suggested his team mates needed to take a crash course in cynicism.
"In the last three away matches we have had three draws that should have been wins," he said bitterly.
"Why? I think it's due to the youth of this team. We have changed a lot this year and we lack the cynicism that helps one not to throw away chances like the one in Rome.
"They are things that one learns with time and I think the lesson of the Olympic Stadium will do the trick."
Juventus stayed top of the league after Milan lost to Fiorentina but the draw at Roma allowed Inter -- whom they beat 2-0 at home last weekend -- to pull level on 14 points.
"We missed a great opportunity," said Juventus striker Michele Padovano, who scored his team's goal.
In fact, the Roma game was also Juventus's third missed opportunity in the league in seven matches this season and all have been in away matches which they dominated.

At lowly Reggiana, Juventus led 1-0 but allowed the home team back into the match for a 1-1 draw. At Vicenza, now third, the score was 1-1 until Juve were caught out by a defensive error and lost their unbeaten league record.
